Name: SIDURON
Description: Siduron is a member of ureas.

environmental_bioconcentrations.References: (1) Tomlin CDS, ed. Siduron (1982-49-6). In: The e-Pesticide Manual, 13th Edition Version 3.1 (2004-05). Surrey UK, British Crop Protection Council. (2) Meylan WM et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 18: 664-72 (1999) (3) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994)
environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: An estimated BCF of 150 was calculated in fish for siduron(SRC), using a log Kow of 3.80(1) and a regression-derived equation(2). According to a classification scheme(3), this BCF suggests the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is high(SRC), provided the compound is not metabolized by the organism(SRC).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Kearney PC, Kaufman DD; Herbicides: Chemistry, Degradation, and Mode of Action, Vol 1, 2nd ed. NY,NY: Marcel Dekker, Inc (1975) (2) Tomlin CDS, ed. Siduron (1982-49-6). In: The e-Pesticide Manual, 13th Edition Version 3.1 (2004-05). Surrey UK, British Crop Protection Council. (3) Domine D et al; SAR QSAR Environ Res 1: 211-9 (1993)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: AEROBIC: Microbial degradation has been reported to occur in soil using C14-labeled siduron(1). In water and soil, microbial degradation has been reported to occur with a half-life of approximately 120-150 days(2). Siduron has a measured field half-life of 90 days(3).

environmental_biodegradations.References: Spencer, E. Y. Guide to the Chemicals Used in Crop Protection. 7th ed. Publication 1093. Research Institute, Agriculture Canada, Ottawa, Canada: Information Canada, 1982., p. 513
environmental_biodegradations.Value: /Siduron is/ subject to microbial decomp under moist conditions in soil.

environmental_biodegradations.References: Ahrens, W.H. Herbicide Handbook of the Weed Science Society of America. 7th ed. Champaign, IL: Weed Science Society of America, 1994., p. 269
environmental_biodegradations.Value: Primarily degraded by microbes. Certain soil microbes can utilize siduron as a sole carbon source. Two bacterial and one fungal species capable of metabolizing siduron have been isolated.

logP.References: Tomlin CDS, ed. Siduron (1982-49-6). In: The e-Pesticide Manual, 13th Edition Version 3.1 (2004-05). Surrey UK, British Crop Protection Council.

mechanism_of_action.References: Weed Science Society of America. Herbicide Handbook. 5th ed. Champaign, Illinois: Weed Science Society of America, 1983., p. 427
mechanism_of_action.Value: Unlike other substituted urea herbicides, siduron is not a potent inhibitor of photosynthesis; phytotoxic symptoms appear to be associated with root growth inhibition.

soil_absorption_mobility.References: (1) Wauchope RD et al; Rev Environ Contam Toxicol 123: 1-36 (1991) (2) Tomlin CDS, ed. Siduron (1982-49-6). In: The e-Pesticide Manual, 13th Edition Version 3.1 (2004-05). Surrey UK, British Crop Protection Council. (3) US EPA; Estimation Program Interface (EPI) Suite. Ver. 4.0. Jan, 2009. Available from https://www.epa.gov/oppt/exposure/pubs/episuitedl.htm as of Jul 20, 2009. (4) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983) (5) Warren RL, Weber JB; Soil Sci Soc North Carolina Proc 37: 23-35 (1994) (6) Weber JB; Soil Facts: Protecting Groundwater in North Carolina - A Pesticide and Soil Ranking System, North Carolina Cooperative Extension Service, NC, State Univ College of Agric and Life Sciences (1994) (7) Helling CS; Soil Sci Soc Amer, Proc 35: 737-43 (1971)
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: The Koc of siduron is predicted in one study to be 420(1). Using a log Kow of 3.80(2) and a structure estimation method based on molecular connectivity indices(3), the Koc is estimated as 330(SRC). According to a classification scheme(4), these Koc values suggest that siduron is expected to have moderate mobility in soil. A Pesticide Leaching Potential (PLP) Index of 53 for foliar application and 57 for soil application was calculated for siduron using commonly reported Koc, persistence (half-life), and rate of application values(5,6). PLP values of 0 and 100 indicate no leaching potential and maximum leaching potential, respectively(6). Siduron was classified as having low mobility using retention factors from soil TLC using Hagerstown silty clay loam soil plates(7).

soil_absorption_mobility.References: Ahrens, W.H. Herbicide Handbook of the Weed Science Society of America. 7th ed. Champaign, IL: Weed Science Society of America, 1994., p. 269
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: Adsorption increases as clay or organic matter content increases, and as cation exchange capacity of clay increases. The amount adsorbed on Keyport silt loam in equilibrium with 1 ppm in soil solution at 22.5 °C is 2.5 ppm (average Koc is 420 mL/g). Siduron is moderately resistant to leaching. Movement is least in soils high in clay or organic matter and greatest in sand.

plant_translocations.content: In absorption studies with 14-day-old barley plants exposed to a 5 ppm siduron solution, the uptake of siduron-14C by both roots and shoots was continuous over eight days, with roots showing a rapid and sustained absorption compared to shoots. The maximum absorption observed was 0.13 µM, representing 3% of the added 14C. While siduron absorbed by barley leaves did not move into the roots, approximately 50% of the siduron-14C absorbed by roots was translocated to the shoots. The soluble 14C was more prevalent in the shoots than in the roots, with 7% of the absorbed 14C in roots and 6% in shoots being incorporated into the insoluble residue. Importantly, the absorbed siduron did not seem to undergo metabolism into other compounds, suggesting possible intact incorporation. Thin-layer chromatography indicated that only siduron was present in the labeled compound within both root and shoot soluble fractions, indicating its persistence without transformation into other substances.
plant_translocations.reference: Splittstoesser, W. E., & Hopen, H. J. (1968). Metabolism of siduron by barley and crabgrass. Weed Science, 16(3), 305-308.

method.Plant Grown Condition: Seeds placed on filter paper and germinated in Petri dishes. Plants then grown in greenhouse flats filled with potting soil.
method.Chemical preparation: Siduron-14C applied to barley in DMSO at 1% concentration. Siduron at 5 ppm added to solution culture for root studies.
method.Received pesticide of plant: Crabgrass sprayed with 10, 20, or 40 lb/A of siduron.
